conclusion: To determine the radius r_max of a droplet just before it separates from the nozzle, we need to balance the gravitational force with the surface tension force.
The volume V of a spherical droplet is given by V = (4/3) π r^3.
The mass m of the droplet is m = ρ V = ρ (4/3) π r^3.
The gravitational force F_g acting on the droplet is F_g = mg = ρ (4/3) π r^3 g.
The droplet separates from the nozzle when the gravitational force overcomes the surface tension force.
The surface tension force F_σ at the separation point is due to the circumference of the neck, with length d: F_σ = σ d.
At the point of separation, the gravitational force is equal to the surface tension force: ρ (4/3) π r^3 g = σ d.
Rearranging the equilibrium condition to solve for r: (4/3) π r^3 ρ g = σ d.
Solving for r^3 gives r^3 = (3 σ d)/(4 π ρ g).
Solving for r gives r = ((3 σ d)/(4 π ρ g))^(1/3).
The radius r_max of the droplet just before it separates from the nozzle is r_max = ((3 σ d)/(4 π ρ g))^(1/3).
